abstract: Rapid tectonic uplift on the Alpine Fault, New Zealand, elevates topography, regional geothermal gradients, and the depth to the brittle ductile transition, and drives fluid flow that influences deformation and mineralisation within the orogen. Oxygen and hydrogen stable isotopes, fluid inclusion and Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) analyses of quartz from veins which formed at a wide range of depths, temperatures and deformation regimes identify fluid sources and the depth of penetration of meteoric waters. Most veins formed under brittle conditions and with isotope signatures (δ18OH2O = -9.0 to +8.7‰VSMOW and δD = - 73 to - 45‰VSMOW) indicative of progressively rock-equilibrated meteoric waters. Two generations of quartz veins that post-date mylonitic foliation but endured further ductile deformation, and hence formation below the brittle to ductile transition zone (>6-8 km depth), preserve included hydrothermal fluids with δD values between -84 and -52‰, indicating formation from meteoric waters. FT-IR analyses of these veins show no evidence of structural hydrogen release, precluding this as a source of low δD values. In contrast, the oxygen isotopic signal of these fluids has almost completely equilibrated with host rocks (δ18OH2O = +2.3 to +8.7‰). These data show that meteoric waters dominate the fluid phase in the rocks, and there is no stable isotopic requirement for the presence of metamorphic fluids during the precipitation of ductilely deformed quartz veins. This requires the penetration during orogenesis of meteoric waters into and possibly below the brittle to ductile transition zone. © 2014 The Authors.

author_highlights.sentence: δD values of fluids trapped in deformed quartz veins were measured.
Fluid inclusion δD values are not influenced by structural hydrogen using FT-IR.
Quartz vein microstructures are indicative of formation under ductile conditions.
Stable isotopes indicate hydrothermal fluids were rock-buffered meteoric waters.
Surface derived waters have penetrated the ductile crust.

body_text.sentence: In order to elucidate the Southern Alps fluid flow regimes we begin by estimating end-member fluid stable isotope signatures.
body_text.title: Estimation of stable isotope signatures of end-member fluids

body_text.sentence: Veins are composed of quartz ± calcite ± chlorite, but these minerals may not be in textural equilibrium.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Alternatively, the vertical position of the BDTZ may change during seismic cycles allowing fluids to penetrate deeply under hydrostatic pressure before becoming overprinted by ductile deformation as the BDTZ returns to higher levels (Connolly and Podladchikov, 2004; Sibson, 1992b; Wightman and Little, 2007).
body_text.title: Penetration of surface-derived fluids into the ductile regime

body_text.sentence: Fault rocks deformed in a brittle manner are highly altered and retrogressed to green, clay-rich cataclasite (Warr and Cox, 2001).
body_text.title: Geological setting

body_text.sentence: All other veins sampled were formed within the brittle crust (at depths of <6 km).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Inboard Fissure veins: At 5 to 10 km south east from the Alpine Fault, but still within the Inboard zone, fluid flow is recorded by Fissure veins which are typically up to 10 cm wide and commonly contain open space filled prismatic quartz crystals up to 5 cm (Craw, 1988).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: The impact of fluids on mountain building depends on fluid sources, flow paths and temperatures, and extent of fluid–rock interaction at different crustal levels (Yardley, 2009).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Prior to stable isotope analysis vein samples underwent detailed hand specimen and petrographic description; fluid inclusion populations in vein quartz were characterised and subject to microthermometry.
body_text.title: Methods

body_text.sentence: Fluids play a key role in orogenesis through the transport of heat and mass (Bickle and McKenzie, 1987), by changing the rheological behaviour of rocks and localising deformation (Wintsch et al., 1995), and concentrating valuable mineral resources (Weatherley and Henley, 2013).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Veins typically >10 cm wide infill fractures, joints and irregular cavities in wall rock and are principally composed of quartz ± calcite with minor adularia ± chlorite ± mica ± sulfides and rare gold (Craw et al., 1987, 2009) (Table 1).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Such models only allow for the migration of small fluid volumes, and the relatively long stagnation periods between pumping events increases the probability of rock-buffering, in agreement with our rock-buffered fluid δ18O values.
body_text.title: Penetration of surface-derived fluids into the ductile regime

body_text.sentence: Highly altered, cataclastic brittle fault rocks crop out directly adjacent to the Alpine Fault, but ∼25 to 50 m structurally above these, mylonitic schists showing little near-surface alteration occur for ∼1000 m. Both brittle and ductile fault rocks show evidence of fluid–rock exchange and mineral precipitation during deformation.
body_text.title: Geological setting

body_text.sentence: FZ Fissure veins: (Type (iv), Toy et al., 2010).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Foliation Parallel veins are 0.5 to 2 cm wide and are more strongly deformed at higher temperatures and record fluid flow at deeper crustal levels than the 0.5 to 4 cm wide Foliation Boudinage veins.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Main Divide veins: These vein sets are associated with gold mineralisation near the Main Divide and have been sampled in the Upper Callery River and the Burton Glacier (Figs. 1a and b).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Theoretical models indicate that the penetration of meteoric waters into the ductile regime of an orogen is mechanically possible.
body_text.title: Penetration of surface-derived fluids into the ductile regime

body_text.sentence: The presence of ductilely deformed veins, brittle veins, and hydrothermal mineral alteration assemblages suggest that fluids are present in the fault zone from below the BDTZ (>6–8 km) to the surface.
body_text.title: Geological setting

body_text.sentence: Portions of the doubly polished wafers of ductilely deformed quartz veins were analysed using FT-IR to test for structurally bound hydrogen within quartz lattices following Gleeson et al. (2008).
body_text.title: Methods

body_text.sentence: Microthermometric measurements were performed on a Linkham THMS 600 heating stage at the University of Southampton following Hopkinson and Roberts (1996).
body_text.title: Methods

body_text.sentence: These veins occur only in the Alpine Fault zone.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: They are 0.5 to 2 cm wide and are composed of quartz ± calcite ± chlorite ± pyrite.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Foliation Parallel and Foliation Boundinage veins: (Types (i) and (iii), Toy et al., 2010).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Veins cross cut mylonitic foliation (see Fig. 7, Toy et al., 2010) and are further ductilely deformed, as shown by quartz and calcite grain microstructures which are indicative of ductile deformation (see Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Materials).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Doubly polished ∼250 μm thick slices were prepared from quartz veins for fluid inclusion observations and FT-IR analysis.
body_text.title: Methods

body_text.sentence: These millimetre-thick crusts on joint surfaces are composed of quartz ± calcite ± chlorite.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Joint Coating veins: Mineralised joints cross cut earlier, deeper-formed brittle structures which host FZ Fissure veins in the AFZ and are inferred to record fluid flow at shallow levels (<2 km).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Crustal fluids have distinctive isotopic ratios depending on fluid sources and flow paths that can be used to identify end-member fluids.
body_text.title: Estimation of stable isotope signatures of end-member fluids

body_text.sentence: Fluid–rock interaction under ductile conditions is preserved by synkinematic ductilely deformed quartz veins (Toy et al., 2010).
body_text.title: Geological setting

body_text.sentence: Vein samples representative of mineral precipitation over a range of conditions into the ductile regime (>6–8 km depth) were taken from the Inboard and Main Divide zones of the Southern Alps (Figs. 1a and b and Table 1).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: They cross cut the mylonitic foliation and show evidence for limited ductile deformation indicating they formed near the BDTZ.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: These veins are composed of quartz ± calcite ± chlorite ± adularia ± muscovite ± pyrite (Craw et al., 1994; Craw, 1988; Jenkin et al., 1994; Holm et al., 1989; Teagle et al., 1998).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Two types of ductilely deformed veins from the Alpine Fault zone (AFZ) were analysed:
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: Quartz from ductilely deformed veins was investigated by Micro-Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR).
body_text.title: Methods

body_text.sentence: Active deformation within the ductile regime of orogenic belts can create local dilations, particularly where different rock types are present, which allow fluid movement against widely assumed regional hydraulic gradients (McCaig, 1988; Sibson, 1981, 1992a; Upton et al., 1995).
body_text.title: Penetration of surface-derived fluids into the ductile regime

body_text.sentence: Hydrothermal mineral grains were removed from veins, sonicated in Milli-Q (18.2 MΩ.cm) water and purified by hand-picking.
body_text.title: Methods

body_text.sentence: Additionally one sample of a Foliation Parallel vein from Chancellor Dome, ∼8 km south east of the Alpine Fault (Wightman et al., 2006), was analysed.
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: The deepest formed veins display evidence of folding or deformation-induced recrystallisation of vein minerals (Toy et al., 2010).
body_text.title: Sample descriptions

body_text.sentence: As there is no syn-orogenic magmatic activity in the Southern Alps, end-member fluid compositions are restricted to meteoric waters and metamorphic dehydration fluids in equilibrium with Alpine Schist.
body_text.title: Estimation of stable isotope signatures of end-member fluids

metadata.title: Incursion of meteoric waters into the ductile regime in an active orogen
